reviewText:
Early Access Review

I started playing this game late in 2013.  I registered in the beginning of 2014, and my adventure started from there.  This game has been unique to me in so many aspects, I really don't have the room in a review to talk about them all.  The sandbox aspects, the fact it's an indie game by basically a one-man-team, or the fact it's the most expansive space-sim I've played to date, bringing back nostalgia of Freelancer.

One thing that has kept me going is the continuous rise of the community.  Slowly, we had less than five active players for weeks on end.  Then a few dozen in the next months.  Eventually, the game expanded and more players joined, and I really felt the small part of the mysterious galaxy we were all in come alive.  Industry was a boon, mining operations became a thing, and eventually the galactic market was properly being utilized which was surprising to many of us so early on.

I eventually had to take a break to focus on real life, but this game was always great about treating you right.  I could play for 15 minutes or 12 hours a day, didn't matter - I progressed.  I could skip weeks or months at a time, didn't matter, I could start off right where I left off.  It's always been a pleasure seeing the game constantly updated on a daily basis.  It's been even more of a pleasure having a dev who will directly communicate and give his time of day to the players.

I was a skeptic at first, but soon came to truly believe in there being billions of solar systems to explore, everything procedurally generating to be a unique experience every time.  Eventually, players started exploring and graphing charts of planets and moons to settle on.  Then players started constructing gates, expanding the inner systems, and really bringing the heart of the game to life - the reconstruction of the empire of humanity.

It's been over a year now, and myself and other older vets have watched this game bloom like a beautiful flower, and I'm proud to write such a positive review for it.  I could sit and try to come up with excuses all day long, but I honestly can't, this game has been going in the right direction nonstop, and has never ran out of *ahem* Steam.

If you want to see what the game looked like a year ago - and my basic introduction to it, check out my youtube channel:  http://www.youtube.com/sinstrite  There are also new videos being uploaded right now, based on my attempt at a Let's Play of the game.  I don't think a Let's Play has been attempted with a game quite like this, so I find it interesting myself how tough it is to actually product the content.

Here are some helpful links!

http://www.thespacegame.com - play in the web browser for free
http://forum.thespacegame.com/index.php - the official forums
http://wiki.thespacegame.com/mediawiki/index.php/Main_Page - the official wiki
http://www.facebook.com/TheSpaceGame - the official facebook page
http://thespacegame.uservoice.com/forums/194252-general - vote for player ideas

I really do advise the new player to visit the wiki.  Many veterans have put in a lot of work to build it from the ground up, and even as one of the oldest players I still find myself using it constantly.  Let it be your space-bible.

Keep in mind that you purchased the game for $10.00 and paid another $10.00 for the three months of premium bundled with the purchase.  When you first start, do not use your premium right away, save it for when you will most be able to use it.

Planetary Premium - $0.99 monthly - You get access to the six other planets to build settlements on.  As a free player you can only access Ceres for grain and Vulcan for Iron.  You will also be able to produce: titanium, carbon, aluminium, meat, fruit, vegetables.  This is very good for expanding your starbase later on which brings us to...

Industry Premium - $0.99 monthly - Use this to expand your Apollo starbase to 100 rings (600 modules) and really pump out some products with your factories.  You can make a lot of progression this way as a new player, and I highly advise you to get all 100 rings going if you plan on building a colony later on.  This also allows you to use modules above class 5 such as the mining beam, ram scoop, salvage beam, etc.  This really is the best premium to purchase in my opinion.

Combat Premium - $0.99 monthly - If you want to make some credits fighting in Janus A, you want to throw some huge guns on your ship.  With this premium, you can access all weaponry over class 5 which allows you to move to the highest rank, making around 60,000,000 each mission ;)

For you want-to-be colony builders...  You need Stellar Credits.  Each premium gives you 100 stellar credits a month, so if you have all three premiums going, you get 300 SC a month.  A colony costs 80 a month to upkeep, so you can have three colonies just for having the three premiums.

OSB - Starbases that can be attached to your colony in high orbit.  They costs SC if they are not attached, but are free if they are.

/ignore PLAYERNAME is your best friend.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ascent:TSG is the ugly woman you married because she offers more depth than beauty. Her dedication to creating your unique universe is only comparable to the quality friends she keeps and the community services she provides.

You don't want to show her in public, because her graphics are barely comparable to today's modern woman. But at home, between the bosoms of her cozy universe, she offers you to explore her star systems, to probe her planets, and to sample her soil. With some luck, her riches will open.

She is so giving, so free from jealousy, that she bridles your constructive manhood need to do more, to please her by sharing her with people who understand her inner beauty. Her happiness is your ambition, to gather her spoils and to share your discovery with others. Your orbital space base and an extended jump gate will drive her to ecstasy.

She can be complicated as her background knowledge comes from NASA, yet she shares a learning journey of science and physics, with the story of the destruction of humanity and the need to rebuild.  She wants you to be rich with passion and to shape her to your desires. She will remember you as you touch her virgin star systems, prominently etching your name into her universe as you prospect a new facet of her exquisite beauty.

Her attractive secret is her potential to be more than she currently offers. Unseen by other woman you may have experienced, she challenges you every month with new features; a new way to re-discover her warm elegance in a cold universe. Once you look past her mistakes and the silly bugs which make her quirky, she is a passionate lover to your space exploration imagination. She learns from you, gives you enough to satisfy your demands and at the same time, offers a unique gaming experience as she grows. The more you play with her, the better she becomes.

Early Access Review

I started playing this game several days ago before the Steam release because I couldn't wait for the release (with over 40hrs of playtime) I'm glad I did as well. This game is amazing on so many levels. It's well worth the $20.

There are some caveats however that are worth noting to those thinking about purchasing.
The game purchase will get you most of the features in the game except for full colonies. To have full colonies you will need to have a premium account. For all three premium features it costs $3 a month. The point to the premium is to help support the cost of running the servers. Without premium you'll also only have access to one space station ring, with premium you get up to 100. When you purchase the game you will get a 3 month trial of the premium service so you can try out colony building if you so desire.

Even with the above caveat this is still not a pay to win game. You don't need to have premium to have a full immersive experience of the game. Here's a list of the pro's/cons of the game:

Overall rating 9/10

+Huge universe with 270 billion star systems with only a handful having been discovered so far.
+A very friendly and helpful community
+Fast space travel (seriously fast autopiloting system & warp gates)
+Resource harvesting including asteroid mining, gas harvesting by skimming gas giants, colonies that mine resources
+Smooth stable game play client & server (In over 40hrs of playing I have had the client crash once and almost no lag or latency issues)
+Developer that logs into the server and gets input from his players!
+Good tutorial that isn't overbearing (think breadcrumbs)
+Good selection of ships that aren't too difficult or time consuming to get.

-Registration is a tad confusing for new players and is on the list to be reworked/fixed
-Graphics are not the best compared to other games out there however with graphics at max it still looks amazing
-Need premium to access colonies (as noted above)

Some special notes:
Mining: Mining is not the boring thing I've experienced in most space games where you just find the rocks and shoot them to harvest. In this game the different asteroids have different compositions yielding different minerals/metals. Also the asteroid fields move, so the rocks don't just float in space. You have to match speeds with them and carefully fire your mining laser. The idea is to heat up the rock to a certain temperature to yield the materials. Too cold and it doesn't work, too hot and the rock explodes yielding you nothing. So, you have to pay attention to your mining beam and shut it off at the right time. Also, the range of each class of beam is different, at first you have to get within 1,000 meters to mine an asteroid.

Trading: The game has a very well thought out trade infrastructure and system. Each of the core systems has a NPC Space Station that has a local market where you can sell goods & materials. Each station also specializes in producing one material for sale. Each core station also has a contract board where npc's offer contracts for needed items, passenger ferrying, blueprints for sale (for colonies & player stations), specialized colony supplies/materials, package deliveries etc. The contract board changes every hour, :15 after and :45 after the hour. The Galactic Market (or player market) is where players can offer goods for sale across the whole galaxy that can be searched from anywhere then when bought players have to travel to the selling location to pick up the goods. Also player colonies have stock markets where player harvested goods are bought and sold. With a little bit of time and help from the players you can make a lot of money trading on player stock markets or selling mined goods to colonies.

Warp gates: outside the core 8 systems traveling requires a hyperdrive that burns hydrogen. So if you want to explore you will need those things and have some good skill in gas giant skimming. Also over the last several months several of the colonies just outside of the core 8 have developed into core systems and have built their own warp gates to the core systems. There are several gates being built now (requiring huge amounts of resources) these could be opportunites for traders and miners alike providing the resources for such gates. Also if one were to invest enough time and resources into a new system they could build their own gates to and from the core systems making player trading more viable and cost efficient.

Absolutely amazing game. The game is very immersive. Asteroids orbit around planets, you can land on planets to build things there, the crafting system is very complex and interesting, and you can even build your own space station which you can expand with many different kind of modules.

I've been playing this game for about 2 weeks now. First I want to address the most common complaints:

a) It's pay to win? The DLC Bowhead certainly gives you a lot of cargo space with which to make money, since the game doesn't lock ship size to any player stat other than affordability. But the game has access to bigger ships than the Bowhead, all without the DLC. Making credits is ridiculously easy. I have the next ship in size to the DLC one, the Archon, and could have an even bigger one if that's what I chose to focus on. That's after 2 weeks play.

b) hidden subscription? The game does tell you that the $20 current purchase price includes 3 weeks of premium. Not having premium does restrict what class weapon you can mount (meaning you mount more, smaller weapons) and other restrictions. But the sub price is 1, 2, or 3 dollars a month depending on what you want to do in game. Really, I spend that much daily on coffee. Ever since I've been playing MMO's I've been used to $15 a month subscrptions, and that seems fair.

About the positives- love the depth of the game. The longer you play the more you realize there is a lot out there to do, and to learn, and to build! I even tried combat route, which isn't my forte, and found it interesting. There are updates coming to the UI and the combat system. Me, I love the building starbases and colonies aspect of the game.

It's crazy interactive. Take mining for example. Find the right asteroid, match speed and direction of travel, open up your mining beam and heat it up to the precise temperature- less and you reduce the yield, more and you might explode it. All while moving! Swap out ship modules to optimize the ship to your playstyle, balancing space vs utility.

It's.. huge. At my stage of the game I look at the systems far away waiting for me to investigate... and procedurally generated space means there will be more when I get there, generated as I arrive- named after the discoverer! That is still a month away game wise for me.

The dev is extremely involved, and very positive. Check the game forums, won't cost you anything, and see the bug reports and the actions taken. The community is extremely helpful, in advice as well as hands-up, and will steer you right. They are eager to make the game as good as it can me.

Hey, this is where I spend my free time. IF you like social interaction, building, mining, combat, this is it. If you prefer to play with cooperative players and away from player harrasment, this is definitely the place.

Early Access Review

For such a small development team with limited funds and an Early Access state, the game is amazingly stable. Granted I've played for about 4 hours as of writing this, but I have the graphics maxed out and have not experienced a single crash. The game could be a bit better optimized, but I wouldn't expect that at this stage. There's a few little strange graphical glitches but nothing game breaking. For example, if you buy a new ship your UI doesn't reflect the new stats unless you go back to the Main Menu and then load the map again.

On that note, this reminds me of Eve. It's a massive grind to get good progress and the game is insanely overwhelming; however UNLIKE Eve, you can get a solid grasp on the game within a couple of hours and it's all easy from then on. If you have questions, the community is very nice and mature and is always willing to help you.

So far I haven't had the opportunity to build anything yet, the few hours seem to be all about delivering goods and giving people rides to other space stations so you can earn anough credits to buy bigger ships. I haven't even touched the surface of the game and so far it's pretty impressive.

It's about as intuitive as you can get for such a massive scale space MMO. Until my view of this game changes, this post will reflect my current opinion.  An excellent game with a very active developer.

reviewText:
Let me preface this by saying that yes, this game does run on a premium system, however the pricing is quite reasonable, and the game comes with a generous 3 months of full Premium time already paid up. (The best part about this is that the Premium time from buying on Steam isn't immediately applied to your account, you can activate it whenever you feel you're ready to start using Premium features). After that, Premium is priced on what features you want to use - managing colonies on planets in the Inner Systems, managing large-scale Industry, and taking part in combat are all counted separately, so if, like me, you plan on mostly running a manufacturing operation, you can pay just $1 a month and still enjoy what the game's got to offer for you. Personally speaking, I'm planning on going the full $3 a month anyways, this developer can definitely use the support!

As far as space games go, I've been looking for one that allows me to participate in trade and industry in a non-combative manner, and I've gotta say Ascent so far has pushed all of the right buttons! Think of a large galaxy and a player-run economy like in EVE Online, except entirely PVE, so there's no need to worry about more experienced players rolling by and ruining your fun.

Quite the opposite, the community has been super helpful for me so far, and I've gotta say I appreciate that kind of spirit!

The controls for flight are simple but not overly so - You can navigate between gates and stations using just the mouse, and flying your ship in combat uses the WASD keys to pretty solid effect.

The mining in the game also feels just right - No sitting around like in EVE, and no chasing asteroid chunks like in Elite Dangerous, but you have to match the speed of the asteroid to get a good bead on it, and then use your mining laser to heat it up to just the right temperature to get the best yield out of it.

I'm still just getting started with regards to building colonies and space stations in the game, but I really like what's been done so far! There are still some minor issues regarding framerate and loading screens, but the developers have been super active and engage the playerbase on a frequent basis, so I'd say even if you decide not to buy the game today, definitely keep a close eye on it!

Early Access Review

Firstly, ignore the hours on record; I have invested a lot more hours in this than is shown here, however a lot of other players in the community has spent countless more than me :)

Ascent is a genuine space-based sandbox where depth triumphs over flashy graphics and CGI and actually provides you with a genuine sanbox experience where you have the freedom to go anywhere and do whatever you want. Outside of the initial tutorial (Which covers all the basics of the game), nothing is necessary to complete to progress in the game how you want (Even the story missions are optional).

Do you want to make your fortune by travelling to distance systems and mining rich resources? Or, would you rather spend time jumping to systems 100's of light years out from the inner 9 systems and discovering what new worlds the procedural generated engine generates (Which can be marvels to behold, including purple methane oceans)? Or, take on the pirates of the universe and help clean-up the troubles in Janus-A on behalf of the UAE? Or, buy up all the resources available and become an industrial manufacturing mogul? Or, colonise remote systems and begin harvesting raw materials to sell back to other players?

On top of the sandbox approach to this game, the other main strength is how the player base has shaped and expanded on the game. Not only is the economy in the game driven by the players (Pro tip: sell all mined Niobium and Tin to players and not NPC's), the players are also deriving their own content and expanding the known galaxy beyond the inner 9 star systems. From building remote colonies and star bases through to jump-gates to remote systems to connect remote colonies to the inner 9 without the need to use a hyperdrive, the player base and its strength will be what keeps the content generation going for a long time to come. Also, there is a democracy at play where players have the ability to vote for their president, as well as senators of star systems, governors of planets and even mayors of colonies.

Lastly, a lot of the content in the game doesn't require you to be online to achieve. For example, colony builds will occur within a period of 24 hours (Usually), which happens even if you are offline. This also applies to any manufacturing or production you currently have at your colonies or star bases. This means that if you ever take a break for a couple of days, or have limited time to play, everything you have will keep manufacturing/producing without you.

Ascent already has a lot of content to keep casual and hardcore players alike interested for a long time and with the up-and-coming features (Such as PvP and larger ships) it will only get bigger and better over time. Well worth the small monthly fee + initial purchase price.

This week marks my first month in Ascent, The Space Game. What a ride! First off, everyone has a different reason for playing these types of games, and for the most part this game should satisfy an itch whether it's in trading, crafting/production, economies, exploring, discoveries, colony building, and much more.  The emphasis is PVE, but there will be a PvP component in the future.  But I really want to discuss my play this past month.
I am one of those guys that enjoy the journey, rather then the destination.  And this game hits my spot.  Yes, the beginning is tough when you start on a small ship and 1,000 credits and you hear people on chat talking about millions and billions of credits.  But I decided at the very start that I would invest on a foundation to support future play.  I did the early quests, and settled on the inner 8 planets.  As I did this I slowly raised my ship level.  In my style of play I did not use chat to beg and cajole people to give me ships or money to move along quickly.  I had watched Sinstrite's videos before playing and then looked a little at the wiki, so I had an idea what to expect.  After my 8 settlements I built my ISB (Inner Starbase).  It has 100 rings but I found that I only needed 60 or so to be productive.  I scanned dozens and dozens of wrecks and claimed many blueprint fragments for higher level ships.
So where am I today?  I am still in a Mammoth, and not a Seraph, which is a much bigger ship, but I am fine with that.  Amazingly, I have already built 5 Mammoths in my shipyard which I sell to other players.  I have built my first colony and outside starbase (OSB) so now I have two shipyards working, increasing my production effort.  My colony is growing, and I am looking through the 100 new systems I discovered myself to find a suitable second colony.
The game keeps going.  It is what you make of it.  The people in the game are extremely helpful.  Hey, if you want someone to give you a leg up with a better ship and credits you could probably fine someone, and there is nothing wrong with that.  This game has something for everyone. This economy is player driver for the most part.
I heartily recommend this game.  If you see me, wabasco, in game.. give a shout!

Early Access Review

The premise of the game is excellent, and with additional work on graphics, a better tutorial, contract management it could be a great game. The UI is poor, some of the text boxes have a black background so you can read them, and the rest have transparent backgrounds making them almost impossible to read at some of the space stations - especially if another ship happens to be docked in that view area.

You can get as many contracts as you want, but some mysteriously disappear in transit. I have been using a spreadsheet that has the various resources and specials listed in the rows and the stations listed for the columns. Each can show 9 contracts, who supplies what, and shows passengers and packages. At every station that I dock at, I go through the scrolling window and verify which contracts were fullfilled or just disappeared so I know exactly how much I need to get and deliver. For instance I know Elysium is the supplier of Titanium, and on my spreadsheet I see that I have a contract to deliver 56 units to Orion, three contracts with Mica (52, 44, and 34 units) and 34 units to Solaris. I have color coded the space stations so I know which warplines they are on. So I know I have to jump to Mica first, in order to continue down that warpline to Solaris.

I have been able to upgrade ships quickly, so I am in a class 5 now and almost ready to buy a class 6. Unfortunately, I am not able to hire a pilot to run the old ships even though in the manage ship section there are text buttons for pilot and crew. You can sell your old ships on the galactic market, but you can not get back to your listed ship to change price or take it off the market. I have never received a notification of a listed ship being sold so there could be my class 1, 2, 3, and 4 ships still up for sale.

A recent update gave us the option of turning off the white screen that shows during a warp. Unfortunately, we do not have any control over the rest of the psychedelic warp screens which show for way too long. There are no controls to set up a transit route or a trade route. If I had 58 iron, 42 grain, and 60 fruit in the hold and I am going from Andromeda to Plato to deliver the iron contract, then to Archon for the grain delivery, and finally to Solaris to deliver the fruit I have to manually select each warp gate and each station. So it would 12 warp segments to accomplish those deliveries. Each individual segment has to be done separately after sitting through another long viewing of the same psychedelic warp scene. Even cheap GPS units today allow you to do a trip plan with intermediate stops. Surely a civilization that has the technology to build warp gates and space stations could concieve of a better trip planner.

At some warp gates a fuzzy red blob will come flying at you then execute a 90 degree turn and fly off into the heavens. Since the ship or shields have never been damaged, I have to assume that it is not someone attacking me.

I have bought blueprints for each of the bays in the private space station and for a farm on the surface of Ceres. Building will not commence though until you deliver all of the raw materials needed for each section. I have tried to deliver the farm robots and some material to the surface, but could not offload anything. I ended up stuffing everything in the hanger with the hope that it will become clearer with more gameplay on how to actually initiate building and delivering of goods.

It is in early release and the developers are steadily working on the bugs and player feedback so I am hopeful that the UI, trip planning, building, and overall look and feel will steadily improve. Right now it is just rote grinding, upgrading ships, and slowly assembling the parts to have a private space station and surface farm.

Early Access Review

I've played this game 4 days now.  And the clock says I've got 48 hrs in.  That's with logging in to play, exiting when I am not playing.  Needless to say, this game has grabbed my interest in a way that other games haven't.  The last game I got this interested in was WoW back in 2005.

This game is a space exploration, mining, building, crafting, MMORPG.  There is a Galactic Market (auction) that you can put your crafted or used items on.  There are contracts from NPCs you can run to get credits.  There is limited PVE but no PVP (yet).

It has a rapidly expanding community, as it was *just* released on Steam EA a few days ago.  There are a few die hard Kickstarter supporters that are firmly entrenched and know everything, a few middle of the roaders, and a bunch of noobs fast gaining experience.  The community is typically friendly and helpful.  They never seem to tire of answering the same questions over and over from the newest noobies.  They are charitable with advice, and occasionally ship upgrades.  The game developer actually logs in and chats with players fairly often, answering questions and generally being friendly.

One concern I always have coming into a game where some have been playing it for a while is that they tend to stake out their claims to the best of whatever resources you can find.  They have the best gear, and I hate playing catch up ball.  However, this game has 270 billion (with a b) explorable star systems.  Everyone can name a system after themselves, and colonize a planet.  And everyone else can come visit.  And as to gearing up, it happens quickly.  You progress from a tiny ship to a humongous ship in your first few days.  There are more things to aspire to (ie bigger ships yet, starbases, colonies, star systems named after you), so there is always room to grow.

The pros of this game are it is fun, has a great community, a lot to do, and loads of potential.  The cons are a somewhat clunky interface (sorry Jam!), and that it is still a work in progress.  But it is a fun, playable, very social work in progress.

This game is well worth getting.  If you have read this far, you are wasting time; go get it and get exploring!

I would gladly recommend this game.

Disclaimer - I have been gifted a free key for this game for review purposes, however my review will be kept as truthful as possible, since I am meant to help developers and buyers/gamers.

Ascent - The Space Game Review

Overview

First of all, this game is not suited for every single age group. If you were born in the 80's or 90's, they you should probably like it due to the nostalgia level graphics of a AAA game made in that time period. Also, for fans of outer space, space ships, mining ,farming, ect, then this game is going to be a great idea to buy during a sale.

You can: farm, sell items, buy items, mine, get destoryed by Enemies, get more ships, upgrade your ship/s in many ways, destroy enemies, explore 270,000,000,000 (270 billion) star systems worth of:  exploration, colonization, starbase construction, research and technology, mining and farming, trading and combat.  Also, outside the first sector, everything in game is made by real players. There's some spects of 'City simulation' involved, but I didn't discover completely yet. The game is so much cheaper than EVE or Elite: Dangerous, while it also having some fast developement speed, awesome and trutworthy community plus many of hundreds of hours making the game play for you, make it what you want! If you want a City simulator, then so be it. Like mining? Do that then.

Gameplay

Oh boy, where to start. The tutorial is a bit floaty and hard, especially the part  where you need to fight a weak drone. You spend ages just aiming at it since the ship is so light and moves so fast while also sliding too far. Then, once it is in sight, you can spend ages shooting at it, after quite literally 30-90 minutes, you have finished the drone part, which is where I quit the tutorial and went onto the game itself. After the tutorial is done, spend a lot of time finding the icon for the Autopliot (which is transparent until you hover above it), and then spending around 10 minsutes doing the firs fex missions. Then the real fun part is trying to find out what to do on your own. Farming? No, can't conolize a planet yet. Destroy ships? Nah, can't find any. Destroy Asteroid and meteorites? Yes, then sell it all for cash. After the first 60 mins of gaming, you should have around 10K cash, which you can do quite a lot with.

Graphics

The graphics might not look like much, but they are still quite pretty, also, it keeps the loading times less than 5 seconds! So that right there is a giant point to the finalized score. Anyway, moving on. The graphics are what you would expect from an Early Access game midway-nearly finished developement. Anyway, these are still some pretty graphics and are satisfactory for my needs and, hopefully, the majourity of the audience can agree with me on this topic.

Current Content

This is where beauty truly met the eye. As I already said in the overview and gameplay topics, this game has some of the .ost in-depth systems ever to be in a video game. So think of EVE + Elite Dangerous, a game based around space and becoming a high rank withing the community by upgrading ships, colonizing your soon-to-be empire and so, so much more to come. The developers are awesome, they listen to feedback, do Kickstarters to help out with lots of different subjects (one of the most recent one was for the games graphic improvements), but, in my opinion, the HuD is very ugly. the Chat has its own HuD, most things do, but it's a try-hard at doing a futuristic orange 6th grade art project

Pros and Cons

Pros:
Graphics are quite pretty
So much actions waiting to be completed
Quests that aren't all terrible
You need to put loads of work into getting enough money to buy something, which then is so rewarding
Very cheap for it's content count
Trustworthy community

reviewText: Very fun concept, but crashes *CONSTANTLY*. Monthly subscription system is a major turnoff, too. Comes with a few months by default, which is nice, but there's a huge wall of grinding between you and getting to a lot of the features the game is advertised for. I have over a dozen hours and I'm still literally just grinding cash, trying to get a spaceship capable of going exploring out into the systems outside of the base 9. Most of this grinding is done by clicking autopilot buttons. Settlement and star base construction system has absurdly dumb crafting times (time per module is measured in a number of real time hours, often numbering above twenty - freaking - hours!). Number of colonies and star bases you can have is based on how much real money you spend per month - you can go and buy bigger subscriptions to get more planets. Your control over the planets you colonized is based on how many people have built colonies there and how willing you are to involve yourself in the politics process. As in, in-game elections and such. Which is an interesting concept, but I hesitate to see it in practice as it strikes me as a potentially nasty means of griefing. Combat is *extremely* clunky and awkward, and the radar system is in desperate need of a revamp. Indicators are small and difficult to make out unless you expand the radar, which makes it difficult to aim your frontal guns, which are fixed with your movement. There are broadside and 90 degree cone turrets, but those are totally automated and have no player input beyond placing them on your ship. As far as I can tell, there are no variety in weapons, and combat is restricted to one zone.\n\nAll in all, this game strikes me as something I would expect to see out of an alpha. The graphics are rather weak compared to performance (I have a Radeon r9 380, 8 core AMD processor, and 16 gb ram, and my FPS on the second worst setting ranges between 60 to 30 in normal play, but the game's actual material in peak settings is on par with something that's like, ten years old?), it crashes pretty much once per hour. Sometimes those crashes are severe enough to require a hard restart of my PC -- I checked on the forums and this isn't an isolated incident, either, and has happened to people on a wide range of systems - on high end to low end computers. Combined with the massive grind wall to get access to the content with even a shred of depth, and this game was a huge let down for me. I *really* wanted to like this game, but *DO NOT* let the trailer fool you. It is *not* what it's advertised as.

Ascent is a truly wonderful game, offering the most pure fun I’ve had with any game in a very long time. As to gameplay, I am able to immerse myself in the game’s premise, that we are struggling to recover and rebuild the high civilization we’ve lost. As a number of other players have done, I have developed my own tools, primarily spreadsheets, catalogs and calculators, to record my own exploration and production data. What has been for some an inconvenience has been for others an element of realism.

At the same time, I am able to engage the community’s meta-game, expressed on the forum and wiki, in the lively chat flow, and now, perhaps, here in the Steam forum.

Finally, Ascent is the kind of game that allows me to step back when RL demands. When I return, I’ve suffered no loss.  Jam has added new features. My colonies have kept producing. My fellow players have devised new plans and projects, all of which enhance my game.

It’s just pure fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well worth 15 dollars.

-Pros

- Works with xbox controller under pinnacle game profiler flawlessly
- A newtonian colonization sci fi experience that you could easily spend 100-1000 hours on
- Only one developer, but is extremely active, releases patches regularly and can be spoken with in-game easily
- A friendly community that doesn't care to help noobs
- Nearly 3 billion star systems, and ones you discover are named after you forever
- Good newtonian physics
- Awesome ship diversity - i'd guess there are 20-30 ships in the game but they are very robust and more are being added
- NPC auto trade system
- Smuggler system
- Extremely complex colony and starbase system that can be customized
- Good soundtrack and atmosphere, in-game AI SAM 5000 is based on HAL from 2001 a space odyssey he's very amusing
- Minimalist gfx, but still a pretty game
- Stargates are developed by a team effort of players
- Planets are terraformed by a team effort of players and it takes like a year
- Advanced gravity and atmosphere based on real newtonian physics
- Skim gas giants for fuel
- Finally a game with interesting asteroid mechanics. you have to chase rocks down manually, point them to a certain temperature to get the best yield results. It also has some cool rare asteroids that feel rewarding when you find them

- Cons

- Confusing monthly fee that is based on tiers and is kind of hidden from you until after you buy what appears to be an online-only client - game is free to play after you buy the client but at a steep cost in the form of restricted features
- Fifteen bucks for no singleplayer
- Doesn't work on Linux even despite being developed in unity
- Ran like garbage on my Macbook even despite being developed in unity
- Playerbase is only 30 to 40 players in the absolute best case scenario, community could die at any moment
- Like most sandbox games, this is only for players who can entertain themselves in a sandbox
- Repetitive trading expected with most space games, but this game is worse because some galaxies have dozens of player colonies so jumping into said system causes extreme lag
- Making colonies and planting domes sounds good and all, but there's alot of research required to get into this game and you need to know that setting up your colonies requires actual console commands and some math skills
- Game rewards players who are the most intelligent and spend the most time, this is a good or a bad thing depending on your perspective
- Combat sucks in this game so bad but it is early access. nobody does combat in this game right now because it is a painfully frustrating experience
- Game is basically a singleplayer experience with an MMO gimmick. There's no function that allows you to team up with other players, and interaction with other players is limited to financial transactions
- Can explore unknown star systems, but all are empty and generic. some planets have no textures whatsoever and look lame. stars only come in three types. some systems might have an asteroid belt with rare spawns but that's about it. you wouldn't want to colonize these unknown stars systems as they are so far away so exploring them is mostly pointless
- No npc missions aside from courier runs (trading) and most aren't worth doing. not much to do in this game if you're not building a colony or a starbase

Should note that the game does have a premium option, you get three months with the purchase and after that it's 1.00 per month per tier to a maximum of 3.00 per month. Premium features include being able to fly class 13+ ships, mount class 13+ weapons, and to have 8 free newbie colonies in the NPC populated core systems.

IMO, having the starting newbie systems for a dollar a month isn't really worth it, except for the fact that without it you can't build more than six rings on your newbie starbase (you get the first starbase free). It's a significant disadvantage as starbases cap out at 100 rings. The newbie colonies are not as robust as the outer colony system and are extremely limited - one can only expect yields of 10,000 resources per colony per half day or day depending on colony efficiency whereas the outer colony systems can yield MILLIONS or even BILLIONS per day as they are huge, and furthermore can yield more than one resource. They can also act as player controlled trade hubs.

Early Access Review

Ascent the Space Game is a wonderful find, I've been playing for months and am not tired of it yet in the least.

The concept behind the game is that you begin piloting a basic ship, and make your way into the universe.  Tutorial missions will guide you at first, and it's definitely worth it to complete these as they will give you access to a plot of land to place some mines on, a Star Base in which you can construct components necessary to colonize worlds, build ships, etc.

The game universe consists of a small core of 9 NPC run inner planets.  Each planet is in a system, and you travel between them using gates.

Outside of that is when the game really begins... as there are millions of unexplored star systems out there.  Players can explore, colonize worlds and build colonies producing minerals, food, alcohol, etc.  Construction of Gates between these systems are large cooperative projects, but there are many already in place and more planned.

Which brings me to the community.  The player community in Ascent is fantastic.  I've rarely felt at home in a game like I do in Ascent.  Certainly one of the big selling points to me.

Another positive for me is that PVP is not really an issue.  Roughly a quarter of the Galaxy is designated for the Red Zone"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the second game I randomly found on Steam that I've never heard about but is actually fantastic. A True sandbox space (I don't even know how to classify the type of game this is because it feels like we can do anything we want... explore, trade, colonize uncharted planets, improve yourship for combat, etc).

My ship's on board computer has a commandline that allows us to set parameters (quite frankly this was totally unexpected for me, and it adds to the cool factor for me).

There is trade, there is massive exploration opportunities, probably more starsystems than will ever possibly be explored even if this game is around for 20 years.  100s of billiions of stars out there, and we can set up a colony and our own space station eventually.  I'm impressed.

This game appears to have all the features I've always wanted in a space game, and I was shocked at how easy it is to get the hang of.  Although I heard from others using the interstellar communications that the further along we are in the game the more complex it gets.  So I asked them that even if it gets complex can I just still choose to explore, and be mellow.  They said yes this is a sandbox.  They said we could just do the tutorial and take it as slow as we want.

Also it was a nice suprise that ships do not expend energy unless you use hyperdrive to travel to stars without a jump gate.  I also couldn't wreck my ship by crashing into the space station (which was nice since I didn't realize all I had to do was use autopilot to dock my ship).  In any case this is totally up my alley since I don't like micromanaging fuel while still learning a game.  We can keep flying from station to sation, mine, land on planets explore without fear of crashing and blowing up, or running out of fuel until we are ready to go out and take on more deadly stuff.

I don't know folks but this game seems like it is like a real universe.  I read all that stuff on the website about the graphics needing to be better and stuff, but I'm impressed at how immersive this game is and the graphics aren't an issue with me at all.  It also said they were working on improving combat (I honestly haven't tried combat yet, but the list of controlls seem simple enough).  This is still just early access so I totally don't expect this to be feature complete, but my goodness I'm glad I got this game!  I definitely recommend, and I'm not some long term fan boy that is biased about this game.  I really think this is a good find.

Was going to write a Review on the game at 100 hours game play, Reached that within the week and still had not scratched the surface of this amazing game so decided to try it at 500 hours, oops got lost in the game. For a handful of people making this game it truely is amazing.
There is plenty to do within the game and you dont have to sit on a set path to enjoy it. Dont feel like hauling goods?, go kill some npc ships. Dont want to explore?, build up your own base, Dont want to salvage ship parts off wrecks?, go mine asteroids that move and turn around your space-ship.
Speaking of ships the different ships and carrying capacity is mind blowing for an alpha game, zip around in a 6 direction mini-frigate or carry tens of thousands of tonnes of materials in a freighter, trading with friends or npc's around the galaxy.
Like shiney objects? there are about 270Billion of them! all ready to be explored.
The graphics although not as refined as the blockbuster type games are still impressive.
The community is very vibrant and helpful with many of the players spending over 1000 hours logged there is a wealth of knowledge there.
This is a sandbox mmo meaning its not how the game wants you to play but how you want to play the game!

TLDR; Great game too much time typing, must get back and play it!

reviewText:
I've had to re-evaluate my review over the last few days.  I've steadily been getting more and more addicted.  Yes, this game has PLENTY of bugs.  Yes, there are things in it not feature complete coming out of early access.  Yes, it is VERY rough around the edges graphically and UI wise.  But it is still attempting something that no other space game has done to date, and with only 1 guy developing it.

So I must preface my main points with this: If you can't handle bugs that cause the game to crash, delete your colony buildings, or cause your fps to drop below 20 due to memory leaks, DO NOT play this.  You will rage quit.

I'm still learning the intricacies of this game.  But it's fairly massive in scope.  You will spend many hours learning how to build colonies and work on your personal starbase.  If you follow the tutorial you should be fine.  The game needs alot of work even coming out of early access.  You will get glitchy graphics here and there.  Pirate AI vessel's will usually glitch out and constantly ram your ship, making it easy to dispatch them because they just keep moving forward in front of you and not shooting their weapons.  So yeah, shooting them is really easy when they're a foot in front of your nose.

This game was made to build colonies and starbases with.  It has a HUGE universe.  Something like 250 billion planets.  Each new system you warp to is procedurally generated.   You can land on all the planets in the game.  Something that Elite Dangerous doesn't have yet and wont have for awhile.

So keep in mind what I said.  This game was made to build colonies on planets.  The rest of the game isn't fully fleshed out yet.  If you want to make money, buy a bigger ship, strip it, and just mine asteroids all day or collect gas from outer bases, then sell.  Combat will get you some decent money as well because the ships are glitched right now and pose very little threat.

This game is a carebear game.  You can't lose your ship or die, ever.  If your health gets too low, the ship computer auto warps you out of the combat area.  You don't even fight other enemy ships unless you're in ONE particular system.  So taking all that into consideration, you can tell the developer wanted this to be a colony crafting space game with some minor combat content.

You have various skills that improve with use.  I love this skill system and wish more MMO's used it.  The better the skill is, the more money you'll make while doing that activity.  Unfortunatly combat doesn't have any skills as far as I can tell.  Only gas harvesting, mining, trading and colony maintenance.

The colony system is very in depth.  Crafting buildings on planets comes with alot of maintenance on your part.  The people will need food stores and other various activities to maintain morale.  On the flip side, the colonies will produce resources for you.  You can land on your colonies and the colonies of others, get out of your ship and do things like take soil samples, visit another players nightclub or bar and recruit NPC's to fly your ships for you, etc.  Colony expansion is the reason to play Ascent.  It IS the endgame.  Ascent is primarily all about colony construction and building outer starbases throughout the universe to expand the dwindling human race.

Outer planet colonization is much differant than inner 9 colony maintenance.  Think of the inner 9 planets as the starting worlds all noobs visit to learn the game.  Outer planets require environmental domes to sustain life on them, unless they have oxygen and nitrogen in the atmosphere, otherwise, they are like any earth like planet.

All the jump gates in game were created by other players.  So if you want to explore, you need a hyperdrive.  So the player base is pretty nice from what I've seen and help players get hyperdrives for cheap.  THere are players here that have played Ascent for over 2 years now.  So the jump gates are pretty common in the core worlds.

The dev is planning on implementing pvp in a certain zone and that's all.   This game, again, is primarily to avoid gankers.  So if you're coming here from Eve Online and want to screw with people, you won't get that chance here.

This game has a few broken features, like combat.  So the only other thing to do to make money is trade carbon from one system to another.  Making money is soooooo easy once you get to a class 8 or 9 ship. You will be making upwards of 92 mil/hr just trading from one system to another. It's ridiculously easy. I'm in a class 13 ship at the time of this review, and am making 3 billion credits per hour hauling carbon.  The game turns into a time waster grinding money for hours to get a bigger ship to make even more money.  Like I said above however, this game is all about rebuilding humanity one colony at a time.  So the players base is supposed to work together to build bases and colonies on all the planets and build star gates so travel is easier. That, is end game.

reviewText:
I really really really want to like this game, really really really bad. But I just can't.

My original review said that this was a great game, and I still stand by it, but they did exactly what I was hoping they wouldn't: they released too soon. The game was great for a beta, but not for a fully released game.

In my earlier review, I sorta skated over all the negative aspects of the game (glitches, akward gameplay, tedious monotony) because I was seriously hoping that they would be fixed BEFORE release, but they weren't. They did fix a few things, such as the UI isn't as butt ugly as it once was, but that's about it.

Many aspects of this game just feel unfinished, unpolished, glitchy, and clunky. Not to mention the completely unbalanced economic system. New players into this game will never be able to match the prices of some of the veterans. Ever. Including those that haven't played in *literally* months. The veteran players' automatic systems keep racking them in money over time selling at prices you'll never see a profit from.

This game isn't even in beta, it's in alpha. He's still adding features to it without fixing some of the bugs and glitches that are already in the game. I know how it feels to work solely on bugs and glitches, it's incredibly boring and tedious. This game was made by one guy and he'd rather work on adding more fun and exciting features. I get that. I really do, but this game just isn't finished. It's not polished enough to take it out of early access. This is literally the first thing I tried to warn him about in the original post of this review. He released to soon and it's score is plummeting because of it.

Playing this game right now is extremely frustrating. I want to like it I want to like it I want to like it, but I can't. It'll take some major updates to change this review from a negative back to a positive again.

P.S. After reading some posts on the forums, Jam (the developer) has all but run out of money and time for this game. So I doubt it'll ever be fixed enough for me to change my mind once again. ;_;
